lol @ Internet badasses below who are criticizing the kid's aim. There is a 
difference between calming shooting at a target at a gun range and then 
trying to hit a moving target in an actual situation with a weapon that is 
not meant to hit at a target beyond 20 ft. Plus, even at the firing range 
there are common issues that people have that cause them to miss, even a 
non-moving target 9 feet away. One is anticipating recoil, which causes 
your shots to go far lower or miss entirely. The slightest movement of your 
aim could make the bullet miss completely or end up hitting something you 
did not intend to shoot, which is another reason why you don't try to shoot 
a bad guy who has a hostage, for instance, or if there are any bystanders 
in the general direction of where you are shooting. Even with scoped 
rifles, people can miss because they shake, anticipate recoil, close their 
eyes (yes people do this), or fire too quickly.﻿

a lifetime, the 1/4 or 1/5 is accurate. But in terms of how likely it is 
each year you live in a place.. that's different. There are a LOT of

likely to be raped in a poor neighborhood, just as you're more likely to be 
robbed or assaulted. The same goes for poor lighting conditions, faraway 
police stations, time of day/night, and even unemployment rate. It's a bit 
disingenuous to generalize that stat, since it varies from place to place.

the UFC. Usually it's less than 5 punches being thrown before a victor is

Even as a guy, I've been sexually assaulted, by men and women, as well as

stand up for (and if necessary defend) yourself is a nice trick to have. If

+Zoltan slayer of trolls and lost sheeple No I don't care if you agree with 
me for good reasons. But you're completely misrepresenting TYT's position 
and given that you have the actual word troll in your name, I chose to call 
you one. But let me just explain some of the laws TYT supports that I can 
remember just off the top of my head.

1) Universal Background checks: This will ensure gun buyers won't be able 
to buy guns with loopholes we have now with online purchases and fun shows. 
These background checks will be mandatory to make it harder for mentally 
ill or potentially violent people to acquire them. Because as you'll see 
with the rest of these proposals I'm about to list out, the end goal is to 
keep the guns out of the hands of dangerous people and keep gun owners 
accountable for these dangerous weapons they've chosen to buy.

2) Mandatory Gun Safety Program - This makes sure there is a standardized 
program that'll make sure all gun owners (and possibly their family 
members) know how to shoot a gun, load it, blah blah blah. As it is now, 
some gun owners are more ignorant about how handle their weapons than 
others. This will ensure that people aren't a danger to themselves and 
other people. I've heard ideas of gun ownership cards, similar to drivers 
licenses but I'm not if most of the panel on TYT agrees with that or not.

3) Reduced Ammunition Capacity - This is directly make it harder for mass 
homicidal shooters go on endless sprees. If they somehow get their hands on 
a gun and start shooting up a school then at least they'll have to reload 
their weapon more often giving bystanders a window of opportunity to subdue 
the shooter.

I could go on. I could've put more details in the proposals TYT and many 
others support. I could've addressed possible counterarguments but TBH I'm 
lazy for that sooo 😝 But at least notice that nowhere does TYT support the 
prohibition of guns. That's crazy and they've even said themselves that'd 
it'd be impractical, almost impossible given the amount of guns already in 
circulation. We already regulate cars, medicine, food and a bunch of other 
things. Why not guns?

stopping drugs from crossing the border, the more drugs we have coming into 
our country. Do you think the U.K. would have lower rates of gun crime if 
you were bordered by Mexico? I think not. If we were to ban guns here in 
the U.S., we would essentially be announcing an open invitation for 
organized crime and criminals in general to confidently carry out their 
criminal actions against a public they know cannot defend themselves. 

Guns are also illegal in Mexico in case you didn't know, and the murder

+loki2240 Not everyone has the luxury of living in a low crime area. Also, 
the amount of gun deaths due to accidental discharges is a fraction when 
compared to the amount of gun deaths due to crime. All accidental gun 
discharges are due to unsafe gun practices. In fact, the term accidental 
discharge is an oxymoron, since guns cannot accidently fire off rounds. The 
more accurate term would be 'Negligent Discharge'. And lets be clear here. 
As a former veteran, police officer, and current gun owner who luckily 
never had to discharge my weapon in the line of duty, I NEVER want to have 
to be presented with a scenario where I might have to take someones life to 
save my own or others. That doesn't mean however that I would rather NOT 
prepare myself for the likelihood it might happen. You say you'd rather 
take your chances and not possess a firearm because you live in a low crime 
area due to the fact you believe you have a greater chance of injurong or 
killing yourself or someone else from a negligent discharge. If you know 
yourself well enough to know that you are not personally capable of safely 
handling a firearm, I commend you for your honesty and integrity. However, 
if you are coming from a position of fear that random discharges hapoen 
when people handle the weapon safely, you are wrong. And your fear of guns 
is GOOD. Anyone who says that a fear of guns is irrational if you know how 
to use it is an idiot who shouldn't own a gun. Guns are tools, but they are 
tools designed to injure or kill, and if you fear death, then you should 
fear guns. A healthy fear of guns is what drives responsible gun owners so 
practice good gun safety, and combat complacency.

I would assume that your contempt of gun ownership might change if you were 
in fact presented with a life threatening scenario from a home invasion, 
robbery, burglary, or any other situation where owning a gun and knowing 
how to safely and effectively use it could be the difference between 
serious injury/death, or saving your life, your families lives, or the 
lives of others. Just because you live in a low crime area doesn't mean you 
are safe. And as an assumption, I suspect that you, like me, consider most 
people, even criminals, decent people who don't kill indiscriminately. But 
that means nothing when you might be faced with a criminal who doesn't care 
if you are a defenseless father, mother, or child, but who will kill you or 
others anyway, which happens WAY more than it should. 

What I'm saying is, if coming from your sentiment objectively and 
empirically, it is more logical to own a gun, know how it functions, know 
how to effectively and comfortably use it, and practice fundamental gun 
safety, and never need to use the gun, than to be unlucky enough to be the 
person on the recieving end of the barrel of a gun/knife of one or a group 
of criminals where a gun would have given you a fighting chance to protect 
your life or the lives of others. I think this outweighs the fear that you 
may negligently discharge the weapon, unless of course, like a stated 
earlier, you know yourself well enough to know that you wouldn't safely 
handle a weapon.

boys parents for buying him a firearm and teaching him how to use it to

think all criminals live by some moral code of ethics? Is it far fetched to 
believe that had this kid not had access to a firearm that he may be dead

bought him a gun so that he could keep it in his room and play with it

handle 9mm handgun, taught him how to use it, how to safely handle it, and 
that it was to be used only to protect himself should they not be there.

when something like this happened.

+Devon Schmidt The caliber is all-but irrelevant, when discussing semi- 
versus fully auto. I'm sure you can agree that 5.56 on full auto deals more 
damage and/or injures more people, potentially, than a single 30-30 shot. 
The point isn't how much damage you deal to 1 person - people usually die 
from 1-2 shots to the head regardless of caliber, given the minimal range 
involved in being in the same room together. The point is whether or not 
the weapon makes it possible for you to unload on a crowd of people within 
seconds.

A hunting rifle also has stronger recoil, which is almost non-extant in 
5.56 guns. Which means it's even easier to keep on firing with lower 
calibers.

Finally, people dying from gunshot wounds, don't just die from the initial 
damage caused by the caliber. There's blood loss, infections, lead 
poisoning, lethal shock, etc. The point here being that caliber, again, is 
less interesting when determining what kills ordinary people, thus being 
more of a threat to society than a benefit. What matters is the number of 
people that can be injured.

Also, if you're up against 1 deadly criminal, wouldn't you prefer the 
best-damaging weapon over a lower caliber weapon? One that doesn't need to 
be fired more than once?

There's absolutely NO good reason to keep fully automatic weapons at 
civilian gun stores.

+TheFatAssCat +T1Oracle Look, both of you are correct about one thing. A 
gun is a tool, and as any tool, it requires proficiency. 
Both of you are well aware of the potential benefits and the associated 
risks with owning a firearm, one by choice, and another by profession.

You CAN be well acquainted with guns and how to handle them even if you are 
a baker, but you have to admit that it's not your profession to handle 
guns, thus you *should* be better at baking a cake than you are at 
disassembling and assembling your firearm.
If by chance you *are* better with your gun than your spatula, than that 
just shows how much time and effort you've dedicated to handling your 
tool/weapon of choice, but it doesn't guarantee that what you've learned 
about Urban combat is greater than what you *should* have learned about 
being a baker.

While you've probably got enough courage and a steady enough hand to be 
sure of yourself when facing an attacker, you might be at a grave 
disadvantage if your attacker has any sort of knowledge on slightly 
advanced military tactics and combat training, or is just lucky and gets 
the jump on you. The only skills you can get at today's gun ranges include 
proper aiming and safety courses. You can't always expect to have the upper 
hand in any unforeseen situation where all you'd need is a steady hand and 
basic marksmanship. 

Even in a normal day in your life if you are suddenly faced with a life or 
death situation during your working hours, by choice you'd wish you knew 
more about engaging an intruder or had a backup plan set up for the 
situation you might be facing. Let's assume a situation where, if you are a 
decent marksman, you can kill a man at 10 yards, if are a good marksman, 
you can *not* kill a man at 10 yards, and if you are a great marks man, you 
can disarm a man with out hurting him from 10 yards. But even if you are 
the greatest marks man ever, can you properly find cover in time to avoid 
the shot coming at you from the hidden gunman which you failed to notice in 
time? Can you be certain about keeping your calm when faced with a gunman 
trying to take your life? Yes? Great? What about your neighbour Misses 
Paula the florist? Does she have any kind of training for such situations?

And Mr. T1Oracle, tell me, Is knowing all about how your weapon is created 
and assembled, being sure of your gun having no flaws, being trained in 
dealing with jams and broken parts, along with all associated marksmanship 
skills needed for your particular firearm truly enough to make you feel 
safe in *any* hostile situation? Even without all the workouts and reflex 
trainings associated with being in the military, isn't there more things 
required to know about engaging an armed assailant? What about common 
tactics and engagement plans? Lets say you wish to incapacitate your foe in 
lets say a single floored, somewhat large typical suburban house? lets 
assume the suspected thief is unaware of your presence but is quite big, 
armed and quickly heading towards your location, your family yet unaware of 
the danger. Would you trust your military training to help you subdue your 
attacker, hopefully without killing him if you can help it? I'm curious 
about how you'd handle such a situation.

But that said, you have misunderstood my point on having a civilian police 
academy. 

Anyone can aim at a stationary target at short to medium ranges with enough 
practice. But that alone is not enough to assure you victory when faced 
with a real life or death scenario. 

Going to a gun range and firing at a stationary paper target might help you 
aim better, but does it help with the other necessary skills? 

Does it help hit a moving, unwilling, and possibly unforgiving target, in 
potentially nighttime or low visibility situations? 

Does it help if you want to maintain reasonable aim while retreating to 
safe cover, or just moving while shooting in general? 

Does it tell you the best places to hit your target if you want keep it 
alive, and train you in the art of not getting hit by any random joe schmoe 
with a couple days of practice at a random gun range? 

And most importantly, is it mandatory to present a basic level of skill and 
an adequate but through understanding of proper safety measures before you 
are considered a graduate?

Gun ranges do teach you some things and do help if you want to get familiar 
with a new gun, but it's just not enough if you want to get good. I think 
having a real civilian training facility/camp with a minimum of two weeks

The Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments contain a due process clause.

Rights. Due process ensures the rights and equality of all citizens."

+polymath7 Most gun fights happen within 6-12 feet of each other. When I 
was in the military, we trained for a significant amount of time with small 
arms techniques that were intended to make the student efficiently, 
consistently, and quickly draw from the hip and fire a quick succession of 
rounds that accurately hit the center mass of the intended target, all 
without aiming. Because the reality of fire fights happen in seconds and at 
close distances, taking the time to bring a firearm up to eye level, align 
th rear and front sites up with the target, and fire a round will likely 
result in your injury or death, especially if there is no available cover. 
Furthermore, anxiety is only a tiny facet of what happens to the body in a 
real gun fight. Police and military personnel train with firearms the best 
they can to try and mimmick massive adrenaline spikes so the student can 
learn the effects it has on his/her body, allowing them to anticipate it 
and control for it. However, no matter how much you train for it, you can 
never completely recreate the difficulty that comes with massive amounts of 
adrenaline release in the face of possible death by a threat. One of the 
first things you learn in the military or police is that there have been 
several people in from both groups who were expert marksmen who could with 
pinpoint accuracy hit a stationary or moving target on the range, but who 
had been fatally shot in the line of duty because of their inability to 
control their adrenaline. In fact, most all police officers who are 
involved in extended shootings will fire off several rounds (15-30) before 
they hit their intended target or before the are themselves shot. Very few 
people are able to remain calm in a firefight the first time they are 
involved in one and that person is firing back, or coming at them with a 
deadly weapon. Being an expert marksmen on the gun range may be impressive, 
but it won't serve you much good if you have never trained for real life 
scenarios. You train like you fight, and you fight as quickly and 
efficiently as possible. Meaning that if you are inexperienced with 
advanced, practical close quarters gun combat, you will revert back to your 
training on the range. Instead of shooting from the hip, stomach, or chest 
from an unconventional standing or prone position, the focus of which is 
speed on the draw, speed of firing successive rounds at the targets center 
mass, holding the weapon close to your body to save precious seconds, and 
the accuracy of the rounds that can only come with continual training, you 
will draw, extend/lock your arms out, bring the gun sights into focus, aim 
at the target, and fire a round...recoil...sights back on 
target...fire...reset...fire....dead.

+Atl .W Nope sorry, malnourished and underweight are not the same. 

"Malnutrition" is when you eat a diet that is too high or too low in 
particular nutrients such that it causes health problems. It can be split 
into "undernutrition" and "overnutrition". 

The main sign of overnutrition is being overweight or obese. However, 
people with undernutrition can also be overweight if they eat a diet high 
in energy (calories), but low in other nutrients.

So if I give you an example. If my diet consists of 100% high sugar sweets. 
Yes, I will be overweight however, I will be malnourished at the same time 
as I won't be getting any of the other vital nutrients I need. 

So to summerise, malnutrition is not the same as being underweight. People
